newsitem.title: GERMANY: Munich Re says merge will hurt earnings.
newsitem.headline: Munich Re says merge will hurt earnings.

text.p: German reinsurance giant Munich Re said Wednesday that its takeover of American Re would pressure its earnings next year but should result in a positive impact in 1998.

"One and one will not make two in this case, but three," Munich Re Management Board Chairman Hans-Juergen Schinzler told the Boersen Zeitung daily newspaper, referring to his hopes for the merged operations.

Muenchener Rueckversicherungs AG, known as Munich Re, said last month that it would spend $3.3 billion to acquire third-ranked U.S. non-life reinsurer American Re in a bid to boost its share of the world's biggest insurance market.
The move will be a "quantum leap" for Munich Re's U.S. business, which has been relatively underdeveloped so far, Schinzler said.

The Munich Re chief said he was convinced that American Re, which is based in Princeton, N.J., had smoothed out longstanding difficulties in its liability coverage, which led to a net loss of $87.6 million in 1995. He said the U.S. firm was expected to post net profits of about $200 million this year.
Munich Re's $65-a-share offer for American Re is backed by investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., which owns 64 percent of American Re.
